Demand–supply diagram for Question 19. A downward‑sloping demand curve and an upward‑sloping supply curve intersect at an equilibrium point. The vertical axis is Price and the horizontal axis is Quantity. Points O, P, N are on the price axis, Q is on the quantity axis, and R and T mark quantities showing excess demand when quantity supplied is OQ.

instructions.text: In each of questions 1 to 50, choose the option that best answers the question or completes the statement.

questions.question: Scarcity in economics means that

options.text: the economy has very few resources
the economy can scarcely produce anything
resources are limited in relation to wants

questions.explanation: Scarcity is defined as the condition where **limited resources** are insufficient to satisfy **unlimited human wants**; i.e. resources are limited in relation to wants.

questions.question: Economics is often described as a science because

options.text: it makes use of controlled experiments
it uses scientific methods to explain observed phenomena and predict future events
it makes use of field work

questions.explanation: Economics is a social science because it uses **systematic, scientific methods** to analyse data, explain economic behaviour and make predictions.

questions.question: When a variable is associated with a time period, it is
questions.explanation: A **flow variable** is measured per unit of time (e.g. income per year). Stock variables are measured at a point in time.

questions.question: Ufuoma is a consumer. His scale of preference shows that he prefers a pair of shoes to a wrist watch; he prefers the wrist watch to a pair of trousers; he prefers the pair of trousers to the pair of shoes. This means that Ufuoma is
questions.explanation: His preferences are **non‑transitive** (shoes > watch, watch > trousers but trousers > shoes), so they are inconsistent.

questions.question: Air is essential to life but commands no price; diamond is not essential to life but commands a high price. This is the paradox of
questions.explanation: This is the **paradox of value** (water–diamond paradox): necessities may have low prices while luxuries have high prices.

questions.question: The average product of labour in a given period is obtained by dividing the

options.text: number of workers by the total product
total product by the number of hours actually worked
change in total product by the change in the total number of workers
total product by the number of workers

questions.explanation: Average product of labour = **total output / number of workers**.

questions.question: Developments outside a given firm which reduce the firm's costs are called
questions.explanation: **External economies of scale** are cost‑reducing advantages that arise from growth of the industry or economy, not from within the firm.

questions.question: Which of the following BEST describes the production function?

options.text: It indicates the best output to produce.
It relates naira inputs to naira outputs.
It relates physical outputs to physical inputs.
It indicates the best way to combine factors to produce any given output.

questions.explanation: A production function shows the **technical relationship** between quantities of inputs and the resulting quantity of output.

questions.question: A textile firm operates a plant in the North (where capital is expensive relative to labour) as well as a plant in the South (where labour is expensive relative to capital). In the diagram above, the Southern plant will minimize costs by combining labour and capital in the amounts indicated by
questions.explanation: The correct point depends on the exact slopes of the isocost lines in the diagram (relative factor prices). From the low‑resolution image this cannot be determined reliably; consult the original paper or marking scheme.

questions.question: The law of diminishing returns begins to operate when
questions.explanation: Diminishing returns set in once **marginal product starts to fall**, though total product may still be rising.

questions.question: The assumption of profit maximization implies that profit

options.text: is the most important consideration of the firm
is the sole consideration of the firm
assumes an insatiable proportion in the instinct of management
is made in order to break-even

questions.explanation: In theory the firm is assumed to **maximize profit**, meaning profit is its **primary or most important objective**, though not necessarily the only consideration.

questions.question: Total fixed cost measures the cost of

options.text: all assets whose quantity cannot be varied in the short run
all assets upon which the firm has control

questions.explanation: Fixed costs are associated with **inputs that cannot be varied in the short run** (e.g. buildings, major equipment), regardless of ownership.

questions.question: The output at which total revenue equals total cost is known as
questions.explanation: Where **total revenue = total cost**, the firm makes zero economic profit; this is the **break‑even** output.

questions.question: The demand and supply equations for a commodity are given respectively as D = 30 − ½P and S = 8 + ¾P. Recalling that at equilibrium D = S, the equilibrium price (P) and quantity (Q) can be obtained as
questions.explanation: The coefficients in the scanned equations are not clearly legible, so solving for equilibrium from the uncertain equations may not match the original answer options. Please verify with a clearer copy of the paper.

questions.question: A commodity is said to have a derived demand when the commodity

options.text: is demanded because of what it can help to produce

questions.explanation: Derived demand arises when a good (usually a factor of production) is demanded **because it is needed to produce another good**.

questions.question: If all goods were free a rational consumer would consume

options.text: an infinite amount of each good
the amount where marginal utility became zero
the same amount as when each good had a positive price
the amount where marginal utility was the highest

questions.explanation: Even if goods were free, consumption would stop where **marginal utility falls to zero**; beyond this it becomes negative.

questions.question: Which of the following changes in equilibrium price and quantity is as a result of an upward shift in the market demand for a commodity?

options.text: The price falls and the quantity falls.
The price rises and the quantity falls.
The price falls and the quantity rises.
Both the price and the quantity rise.

questions.explanation: An increase (upward shift) in demand with supply constant leads to **higher equilibrium price and higher equilibrium quantity**.

questions.question: One factor which influences the slope of a non-linear demand curve for a commodity is the
questions.explanation: The presence of **close substitutes** makes demand more elastic (flatter), affecting the slope of the demand curve.

questions.question: If in the demand-supply diagram above the quantity supplied is OQ, then

options.text: there will be excess demand of RT

questions.explanation: The correct option depends on the exact positions of points P, N, R and T on the diagram; this is unclear from the small scan, so the official answer cannot be stated confidently.

questions.question: One of the characteristics of an imperfect market is

options.text: a large number of buyers and sellers
a lack of homogeneity of products
an adequate awareness of market conditions by buyers and sellers

questions.explanation: In imperfect markets (e.g. monopolistic competition), products are **differentiated**, i.e. not homogeneous.

questions.question: Total revenue is always equal to

options.text: marginal revenue multiplied by the quantity sold
marginal revenue multiplied by marginal cost
average revenue multiplied by the quantity sold

questions.explanation: Average revenue is price per unit, so **total revenue = price × quantity = average revenue × quantity.**

questions.question: If prices fall in a perfectly competitive industry, the firms in that industry, in the short run will

options.text: keep output at the same level but make losses
intensify the advertisement of their products

questions.explanation: In the short run firms cannot freely enter or exit, but if price falls they will **reduce output** along their marginal‑cost curves.

questions.question: Which of the following is TRUE at the quantity of output where Average Cost (AC) per unit has reached its minimum level?
questions.explanation: The marginal‑cost curve **cuts the average‑cost curve at its minimum point**, so MC = AC there.

questions.question: In the short run, the monopolistic competitor
questions.explanation: In the short run, a monopolistic competitor **may earn profit, break even, incur loss or even shut down** if price falls below average variable cost; hence ‘may close down’ is the safest correct statement.

questions.question: Price leadership is
questions.explanation: Price leadership occurs when one dominant firm sets price and others follow; this is a **tacit (implicit) form of collusion.**

questions.question: The additional revenue obtained by using one more unit of a factor is called
questions.explanation: The extra revenue from employing one more unit of a factor is its **marginal revenue product (MRP)**.

questions.question: In a public company, entrepreneurial functions are performed by the
questions.explanation: In a public (limited liability) company, key policy and entrepreneurial decisions are made by the **board of directors**.

questions.question: The most important limitation on the partnership as a form of business enterprise is the

options.text: legal limitation placed on the number of partners
difficulties arising from having two co‑ordinate heads of a firm
fact that each partner, regardless of the capital he contributes, must have the same voting rights

questions.explanation: Partners usually have **unlimited liability**, making personal assets liable for the firm's debts; this is a major limitation.

questions.question: Under partnership, investors who have no desires to be actively involved in the day‑to‑day management of such organisations are called
questions.explanation: **Sleeping (or dormant) partners** contribute capital but do not participate in daily management.

questions.question: Localization of industries refers to the

options.text: tendency to concentrate industries in particular areas
siting of industries in certain areas
deliberate policy of influencing location of industries generally

questions.explanation: Industrial localization is the **concentration of many firms of the same industry in a particular area** (e.g. industrial clusters).

questions.question: Restriction on credit‑creation by commercial banks can be effected through
questions.explanation: A higher required **liquidity ratio** (or cash‑reserve ratio) restricts banks’ ability to create credit.

questions.question: Which of the following factors enhances the ability of commercial banks to create money?

options.text: Leakage of cash out of the banking system

questions.explanation: A **lower reserve ratio** allows banks to lend a higher multiple of deposits, increasing money creation.

questions.question: In any economy, what is used as money is determined by

options.text: government acceptance of a commodity standard
government acceptance of an inconvertible paper standard
its use as a store of value

questions.explanation: What serves as money is largely determined by **social conventions, laws and customs**, which give it acceptability.

questions.question: The rate at which money changes hands is known as the
questions.explanation: The **velocity of circulation** is the average number of times a unit of money is used to purchase goods and services in a period.

questions.question: Merchant banks perform all the following functions EXCEPT

options.text: provision of credit for overseas trade

questions.explanation: Merchant banks specialise in **wholesale banking and finance**, not retail current‑account services, which are provided by commercial banks.

questions.question: Which of the following is a direct tax?
questions.explanation: **Property tax** is paid directly by the owner to the government; the burden cannot easily be shifted, so it is a direct tax.

questions.question: Which of the following is an indirect tax?
questions.explanation: **Excise duties** are taxes on goods/services that can be shifted to consumers via higher prices, so they are indirect.

questions.question: When a nation is experiencing balance of payments surplus, it is in a better position to
questions.explanation: A payments surplus means more foreign currency is flowing in, enabling the country to **add to its foreign exchange reserves**.

questions.question: Which of the following is a good example of invisible item on balance of payments account?
questions.explanation: **Invisibles** include services such as shipping, aviation, insurance and tourism; they are not tangible goods.

questions.question: Deficit financing is mostly facilitated by the existence of
questions.explanation: Government deficit financing is often achieved through **central bank credit** (e.g. printing money or central‑bank lending).

questions.question: The Malthusian theory of population predicts that growth in food production will

options.text: be at a faster rate than population growth
be at a slower rate than population growth
be more rapid than population growth in the developing countries

questions.explanation: Malthus argued that population grows geometrically while food supply grows arithmetically, so **food production grows more slowly** than population.

questions.question: If aggregate income is N500.00 and aggregate consumption is N400.00, this means that the average propensity to consume is
Which of the following items is subtracted when computing Gross National Product at factor cost by the expenditure method?

options.text: export and property income from abroad

questions.explanation: To get from market prices to factor cost, **indirect taxes are subtracted** (and subsidies are added).

questions.question: Which of the following occurs in the circular flow of economic activities with no leakages?
questions.explanation: In a closed economy with no leakages or injections, **national income = national expenditure = national output**.

questions.question: In estimating the national income of a country, the three approaches usually adopted are the

options.text: avoidance of double counting, final expenditure and value‑added

questions.explanation: National income can be measured by **output (product), income and expenditure** approaches.

questions.question: If technology becomes less capital‑intensive, it means

options.text: an increase in the capital/labour ratio
an increase in the labour/capital ratio
a fall in the labour/capital ratio

questions.explanation: Less capital‑intensive production uses **more labour relative to capital**, so the labour‑capital ratio rises.

questions.question: The most threatening problem for the less developed countries is

options.text: the continual depletion of their soil fertility

questions.explanation: Rapid **population growth** is widely regarded as a major obstacle to development in many less developed countries.

questions.question: An increase in an economy's productive capacity implies

options.text: an increase in the economy's rate of capital replacement
an increase in the economy's capital stock

questions.explanation: Productive capacity rises when there is more capital, labour or technology; here the best option is an **increase in capital stock**.

questions.question: Collectivism refers to the system of management of state enterprises in a
questions.explanation: Collectivism is associated with **socialist economies**, where the state owns and manages major enterprises.

questions.question: The group of unemployed members of a community who are physically handicapped or disabled is generally classified under the
questions.explanation: **Residual unemployment** covers people who are unemployed because of physical or mental disabilities that prevent them from working.
